element_texts.text:
I bury a friend of mine, who was in school with me.
[illegible]. pike.
Sgt. Maston - two fingers
Have not seen Sgt. Bibey for a mo.

Corp. Adams wounded 3 times, was about four ft from me. and in a shell hole just across from me. Cpl. York and Pvt. White are wounded. Cpl. York died on way to hospt. I sleep on ground almost freeze to death
Sgt. Miller shares his mess with me, and drives away the most hungry feeling I have ever felt.

Oct [8.20?] We went over, had some close calls my Pl. lost some of my best m. Shell fire is wicked keeps me ducking. My Lt. wounded while out on patrol 9 days of Hell, we are relieved, Two days of rest under shell fire Back toward the front

Nov, 11 day 11, mo 11 hr The big noise stoped.
Until that time I never figured on nothing, but Heaven or Hell, but now my thoughts are of home.  
Sometime in nov. crossed the Muese, 
On outpost.
Many people that were captured by the Bosh are returning to their homes.  Most of them are French.  Some Belgians, and a few English.

72 hours without anything to eat.
10 men knocked out, 3 killed, and 7 wounded by a shell. Just about 10 or 12 yards from where I was trying to sleep.
a hole a day, am an [unclear] on diging in. 
Cooties are getting brave and thick.

Dec. 20. Caught out in no mans land, with 1/2 of my pl. due to a mistake was caught under a triple barrage, the bosh shells, their m.g. fire, and the entire rifle fire of my company. 2 of my men were killed, and 4 wounded. Was knocked out of the same shell hole two times. My life was probably saved by me being knocked in another shell hole and kocked unconcious

Rifle fire cut my [pullees? supplies?] off. I had a big treat today. Nov. 17 took a bath Had some [bise?] Read a [stesny?] digest. Saw a good looking woman today she was a Belgian But she might have been a Kentuckian. She was a good baker, had the pleasure of feast[ing?].

my eyes as she passed my outpost. It is extremely cold up here. Had the pleasure of changing underwear for the first time since sometime in Sept. The cooties[?] had to beat a hasty retreat. a pesky one pounder drops near my dugout but fails to explode

Will be glad when I can go home. I have not received a single letter since I have been over here. Nov. 28. Thanksgiving, although I am not at home to eat turkey I am glad to alive. In fact I am dam lucky to be alive.

Dinner Nov. 28.
[Hardiaek?]. Poor mans pudding, coffee - C6 O12 H6. navy beans, 32 potatoes. a good meal even at that. Our band played for us this morning. "Homeward bound" made me wish for the rock ribbed hills of old Kentucky. I wonder if all of the boys are still alive. who are connected with this story.

One year ago tonight I placed myself in a very peculiar, but a somewhat pleasant condition. I do not remember of seeing anything, but her dress due to the kindness of a friend I found my way to my room, which at that time was situated in the Boar's nest. Since all this has happened I have walked thru the Valley of Death a number of times, my men were killed by my side went hungry, slept in mud holes and today

I am thankful to be alive, but I wish for the boys, who fough and died by my side for the cause of Liberty and Democracy. nov. 30. (Lexy France I had the pleasure on the night of the 30 of sleeping in a bed I mean a real one. It being the first one since some time in one

Since Sept.
We made a big hike today. We are at Obercorn today. We are slowly beating our way back home. I wonder what the old folks are doing at home? I would like to see Fan tonight.

Dec 3rd I found a place to buy 4 eggs. They cost me the small amt of 1.60
We passed thu the city o luxemburg. It is a beautiful city
My feet are so sore that I can hardily walk
We are but a short distance from the booheline

Young Landin [Lt?] Rossing Iverson Hunt Brown. Some days must be dark and dreary. I have been for the last wk sleeping in old barns. The cooties and fleas are thick. We leave in the morning on our last lap of our march

To the Rhine, Dist. 130 km I would like to be home for Xmas, but the chances are slim.
Dec. 7 1918.
We are on German soil tonight. We crosses the line bet Luxenberg and Boshland this morn we are at [Zewwri?], which is on the [mosella?].
We still have 6 or 8 days more to march.
[photographic postcard: bodies of soldiers in trenches]
[photographic postcard: bodies of soldiers on battlefield]
[photographic postcard: body of soldier on battlefield]
[photographic postcard: bodies of soldiers in trenches]
